questions.text: A 40-year- male presented with complaints of increased frequency, incomplete bladder emptying and pain occurring at the end of micturition. On examination abdomen is soft, hypogastric tenderness is present, no guarding or rigidity. Ultrasound abdomen soft vesicular calculi of size 4 cm. Which of the following is the most common cause of secondary bladder stone?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BOO Bladder outlet obstruction is the most common cause of secondary vesicular calculi

Highyeild:

Bladder Stones : Types : Primary : (without underlying pathology) Primary bladder stones are commonly seen in children in the developing world and are due to nutritional deficiency in vitamins A and B6, magnesium and phosphate and a reduced protein–carbohydrate ratio. Composition: Ammonium urate and calcium oxalate Smooth and Yellow brown Secondary : (due to underlying renal pathology) Secondary bladder stones are most commonly related to urinary stasis from elevated postvoid residual volume due to bladder outlet obstruction Composition : Uric Acid Infection Related stones : Composition: triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) White in colour Clinical Features : May be asymptomatic. Haematuria. Dysuria. Frequency and urgency. Suprapubic pain. Hesitancy and intermittency Investigation : Plain radiograph of bladder Renal Tract Ultrasound or CT Treatment : Stone Punch US Lithotripsy Percutaneous Cystolithotomy Open Cystolithotomy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Neurogenic bladder is the 2nd most common cause of secondary vesicular bladder Option: C. triple phosphate stone is composed of NH4, Mg, CaPO4capo4 and occurs in urine infected with urea splitting organism Option: D. Uric acid stones occur in patients with gout, ileostomies and bladder outlet obstruction

questions.text: A 35-year- male presented with complaints of abdominal pain for 2 days, burning micturition, and haematuria at the end of micturition. No history of fever, vomiting abdominal distention. On examination abdomen is soft, hypogastric tenderness is present, no guarding or rigidity. USG shows vesicular calculi. Which of the following is the most common symptom of vesicular calculi?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Terminal haematuria Terminal haematuria is the most common symptom of vesicular calculi

Highyeild:

Bladder Stones : Types : Primary : (without underlying pathology) Primary bladder stones are commonly seen in children in the developing world and are due to nutritional deficiency in vitamins A and B6, magnesium and phosphate and a reduced protein–carbohydrate ratio. Composition: Ammonium urate and calcium oxalate Smooth and Yellow brown Secondary : (due to underlying renal pathology) Secondary bladder stones are most commonly related to urinary stasis from elevated postvoid residual volume due to bladder outlet obstruction Composition : Uric Acid Infection Related stones : Composition: triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) White in colour Aetiology of bladder stones. • Nutritional deficiency • Urinary stasis (elevated residual volume) • Bladder outlet obstruction • Detrusor underactivity • Bladder augmentation or substitution • Neurogenic lower urinary tract dysfunction • Foreign body • Suture or mesh from previous prolapse/ continence/pelvic surgery • Stone from upper tract • Indwelling catheter or ureteric stent • Migrated intrauterine devices • Infection • Drugs • Indinavir • Triamterene Clinical Features : May be asymptomatic. Haematuria. Dysuria. Frequency and urgency. Suprapubic pain. Hesitancy and intermittency Investigation : Plain radiograph of bladder Renal Tract Ultrasound or CT Treatment : Stone Punch US Lithotripsy Percutaneous Cystolithotomy Open Cystolithotomy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. It is the earliest symptom of bladder stone Option: C. It is the pathognomonic sign of bladder stone

Extraedge:

The cancer detection rate depends on the degree of haematuria, being approximately 20% in those patients with VH but very much lower in those with NVH (<5%)

questions.text: A 50-year male working in a rubber factory presents with complaints of painless haematuria 2episode. He is a known smoker for 30 years. On further investigation, he was diagnosed to have bladder cancer. Which of the following is the most common type of bladder malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transitional cell cancer Transitional cell cancer is the most common type of bladder cancer

Highyeild:

Bladder Cancer Risk Factors : Risk factors for bladder cancer. Smoking 2-5 times increased risk Occupational exposure (aromatic hydrocarbons) • Tanner • Rubber • Paint and dyes • Gas and tar • Hairdressers • Plumbers • Painters Environmental carcinogens Arsenic in drinking water Chronic Indwelling catheter inflammation of bladder • Indwelling catheter • Stones • Schistosomiasis (predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma) • Recurrent infections leading to keratinising squamous metaplasias Drugs • Phenacetin • Cyclophosphamide Pelvic radiotherapy Pathology : Risk factors for bladder cancer. Smoking 2-5 times increased risk Occupational exposure (aromatic hydrocarbons) • Tanner • Rubber • Paint and dyes • Gas and tar • Hairdressers • Plumbers • Painters Environmental carcinogens Arsenic in drinking water Chronic Indwelling catheter inflammation of bladder • Indwelling catheter • Stones • Schistosomiasis (predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma) • Recurrent infections leading to keratinising squamous metaplasias Drugs • Phenacetin • Cyclophosphamide Pelvic radiotherapy Presentation : Painless Hematuria (Most common) Storage LUTS of frequency, urgency, dysuria and recurrent UTI may be present flank pain, weight loss, pelvic or bone pain and lower limb oedema (Rarely) Investigations : Urine CT Urography and MRI of the bladder Cystourethroscopy Bladder cancer can be non-muscle-invasive or muscle-invasive The management of NMIBC is TURBT , followed by intravesical mitomycin C or BCG depending on the risk stratification The management of MIBC is neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by radical cystectomy Options for urinary diversion include ileal conduit, orthotopic bladder substitute, heterotopic bladder substitute or ureterosigmoidostomy The choice of diversion is dependent on patient factors, tumour factors and surgeon experience

questions.text: A 40-year- male working in the dye industry presents with complaints of painless terminal haematuria 2episode and pain for 2 days. He is a known smoker for 20 years. On examination abdominal soft, hypogastric tenderness+, no guarding or rigidity. On further investigation, he was diagnosed to have bladder cancer. What is the investigation of choice for Visible haematuria?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystoscopy Patients with haematuria require lower tract investigation with cystoscopy.

Highyeild:

Haematuria is the presence of blood in the urine. It can be classified as visible (VH, or macroscopic) and non-visible (NVH, microscopic or dipstick) Common causes of haematuria ● Cancer (renal cell, urothelial, squamous cell, adenocarcinoma) ● Stones ● Infection ● Trauma ● Cystic diseases (e.g. medullary sponge kidney, polycystic kidney disease) ● Vascular disorder (e.g. vascular malformations, renal vein thrombosis) ● Nephrological causes (IgA nephropathy, glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, Henoch- Schönlein purpura) ● Papillary necrosis ● Cancer (urothelial) ● Stones ● Infection ● Trauma ● Benign diseases (PUJ obstruction, stricture) ● Cancer (urothelial, squamous cell, adenocarcinoma) ● Stones ● Infection (bacterial, TB, schistosomiasis) ● Trauma ● Chronic inflammatory conditions (IC, radiation cystitis, ketamine cystitis, cyclophosphamide cystitis) ● Cancer ● Benign prostatic enlargement ● Infection ● Bleeding disorders (e.g. sickle cell, ● thrombophilia) ● Anticoagulation therapy ● Urethral instrumentation ● Nephrostomy Patients with haematuria require upper tract investigation with CT urogram and lower tract investigation with cystoscopy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Patients with haematuria require upper tract investigation with CT urogram Option: B. It is the initial investigation done when a patient presents with haematuria

Extraedge:

If no aetiology can be identified on laboratory and imaging studies, cystoscopy is mandatory

questions.text: A 40-year- female presents with complaints of abdominal pain, burning micturition and fever. On examination abdomen is soft, hypogastric tenderness is present, no guarding and rigidity. Ultrasound show cystitis. Which of the following is the most common organism causing cystitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E. coli At least 80% of uncomplicated cystitis and pyelonephritis are due to coli , with most of the pathogenic strains belonging to the O serogroups.

Highyeild:

Chronic inflammatory conditions of the bladder are of multifactorial aetiology but present with a similar clinical picture of urinary frequency, urgency and pain, with or without haematuria Common chronic inflammatory bladder diseases. Idiopathic Interstitial cystitis Infective • Chronic bacterial UTI • Fastidious organisms and parasites (Chlamydia, Gonorrhoea, tuberculosis, schistosomiasis) Radiation therapy Drugs Radiation cystitis Drugs • Ketamine cystitis • Cyclophosphamide cystitis Latrogenic Autoimmune BCG cystitis Lupus cystitis

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. In hospital-acquired UTIs, a wider variety of causative organisms is found, including Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus spp. Option: C. Other less common uropathogens include Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterobacter spp. and Enterococci.

questions.text: A 35-year male presents with complaints of abdominal pain, haematuria and fever, and loss of weight. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with hypogastric tenderness, and no guarding or rigidity. Ultrasound shows cystitis. The urine routine shows pus cells but no organism is seen. What could be the probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Highyeild:

Sterile Pyuria: Pyuria (the presence of white blood cells in the urine)and Pyuria in the absence of bacteriuria (sterile pyuria) indicates an inflammatory response that may still be related to UTI or that may be a response to another pathology such as fastidious organisms (e.g. TB, gonorrhoea), carcinoma in situ (CIS) bladder stones or other inflammatory conditions. Causes: Tuberculosis Gonorrhoea and other STD (Chlamydia ) Viral infection (HPV, HIV, Herpes, adenovirus, BK polyomavirus, and cytomegalovirus) Cyclophosphamide Carcinoma in situ Fungal Infections and Parasitic infection ( Trichomonas vaginalis )

questions.text: A 50-year- female presents with complaints of increased frequency of micturition and abdominal pain which gets aggravated on bladder distention and relieved by micturition. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with hypogastric tenderness+, and no guarding or tenderness. Urine routine shows pus cell-1/hpf, rbc-2/hpf. Cystoscopy shows an ulcer over the fundus of the bladder. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Interstitial cystitis The above case with cystoscopy showing an ulcer over the fundus of the bladder and increased frequency o f micturition indicated interstitial cystitis.

Highyeild:

Interstitial cystitis (Hunners Ulcer) / (Bladder Pain Syndrome) Bladder pain syndrome (BPS) is a chronic condition characterised by pelvic pain or pressure that is perceived to be originating from the bladder, accompanied by one or more urinary symptoms, including frequency, urgency and nocturia The term interstitial cystitis (IC) is often used interchangeably with BPS but represents a distinctive bladder organ-specific phenotype with characteristic cystoscopic and histopathological features as opposed to the systemic phenotype of BPS Clinical Features Disabling bladder or pelvic pain, urinary urgency and severe urinary frequency and nocturia Investigations : Urine Analysis and Culture Pelvic Imaging Cystoscopy Treatment: Conservative: Patient Education, Behavioural modification, stress reduction, dietary alteration and physical therapy Pharmacological: Neuropathic analgesic(Amitriptyline,pregabalin) β3-agonists Oral Pentosan polysulphate(Elmiron) Intravesical: Direct instillation of GAG layer replacement therapies Surgical: Cystodistension and Intravesical BTX-A or SNS

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Cystitis cystica is a chronic inflammatory condition, frequently found in patients with recurrent frequency and dysuria Option: C. Alkaline crusting cystitis is rare and is due to the urea-splitting organism causing phosphatic encrustations on the bladder. Option: D. Tuberculous causes sterile pyuria

questions.text: A 50year male presents with complaints of increased frequency of micturition, fever, and loss of weight. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with hypogastric tenderness+, and no guarding or tenderness. Urine routine shows pus cell-10/hpf, rbc-2/hpf. Ultrasound shows cystitis. A retrograde cystogram is done. The image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tuberculous cystitis Retrograde cystogram shows a thimble bladder which is characteristic of tuberculosis

Highyeild:

Genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB) accounts for 15–20% of extrapulmonary cases of TB Pathology: GUTB occurs as a result of either reinfection or reactivation of old TB granulomas. Blood-borne organisms are deposited close to the glomeruli, causing an inflammatory reaction. Macrophages react and granulomas are formed. If bacterial multiplication goes unchecked, caseous necrosis results in the formation of tubercles. Multiple tubercles coalesce and rupture into the collecting system, causing intermittent tuberculous bacilluria and pyuria Presentation : Renal Function Loss Diagnosis : Urine Culture - Sterile Pyuria in acidic Urine NAAT CTU Management: Short Course ATT(Rifampicin, isoniazid and pyrazinamide are used sometimes with ethambutol as first-line drugs) DJ Stenting PCN Nephrectomy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Cystitis cystica is a chronic inflammatory condition, frequently found in patients with recurrent frequency and dysuria Option: C. Alkaline crusting cystitis is rare and is due to urea-splitting organisms causing phosphatic encrustations on the bladder. Option: D. Tuberculous causes sterile pyuria

Extraedge:

Involvement of the bladder is secondary to renal disease. The disease gradually involves the bladder musculature, which is replaced by fibrous tissue, causing a decrease in the size and capacity of the bladder (‘thimble’ bladder)

questions.text: A 30year male presented with complaints of haematuria, and lower abdominal pain. On examination abdomen is soft, hypogastric tenderness is present, no guarding or rigidity. On further investigation, he is found to have renal calculi, urinary bladder wall calcification and a small contracted bladder. What is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schistosomiasis The above case with complaints of haematuria, and lower abdominal pain with no guarding or rigidity, indicates an infectious cause. Also it is found to have renal calculi and a small contracted bladder. Hence the cause of the condition would be parasitic infection schistosomiasis

Highyeild:

Parasitic infection with the trematode Schistosoma haematobium originates from infection with freshwater snails The parasite penetrates the skin and travels to the liver (as schistosomules), where it matures. Adult trematodes migrate to vesical veins and lay eggs (containing miracidium larvae), which leave the body by penetrating the bladder and entering the urine. The active phase is when eggs are actively being laid, whereas the inactive phase is when the adult has died but there is an ongoing reaction to the remaining eggs Presentation: Swimmer’s Itch Katayama Fever Intermittent Painless Haematuria Terminal Dysuria In Chronic Condition - small, contracted, fibrotic bladder similar to that seen with tuberculous cystitis Investigations : Midday Urine Microscopy - Egg with terminal spines Cystoscopy - Sandy Patches Serology (ELISA) [ In cases where eggs couldn’t be identified] CT Urogram Treatment : Praziquantel 20 mg/kg in two divided doses 4–6 hours apart

Extraedge:

Schistosomiasis is an important risk factor for bladder cancer
